title: Sling
data:
**[English]()** • [中文（中国大陆）‎](/wiki/Sling/zh-CN "Sling/zh-CN")

| ) [![Sling.png](/images/9/93/Sling.png)](/wiki/File:Sling.png) |                                                         |
| -------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------- |
| Name                                                           | sling                                                   |
| Appearance                                                     | sling                                                   |
| Damage vs. small                                               | d2                                                      |
| Damage vs. large                                               | d2                                                      |
| To-hit bonus                                                   | +0                                                      |
| Weapon skill                                                   | [sling]()                                               |
| Size                                                           | [one-handed](/wiki/One-handed "One-handed")             |
| Base price                                                     | 20 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid") (+10/positive enchant) |
| Weight                                                         | [3](/wiki/Weight "Weight")                              |
| Material                                                       | [leather](/wiki/Leather "Leather")                      |

A **sling** is a type of [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, and is a [launcher](/wiki/Launcher "Launcher") designed for [rocks](/wiki/Rock "Rock"), [gems](/wiki/Gem "Gem"), and [gray stones](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone"); these projectiles can be [multishot](/wiki/Multishot "Multishot") when [fired](/wiki/Fire "Fire") from a sling.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Sling skill](#Sling_skill)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Origin](#Origin)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SporkHack](#SporkHack)
  - [6.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [6.3 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.4 DynaHack](#DynaHack)
  - [6.5 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [6.6 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)
  - [6.7 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Slings make up 4% of all randomly-generated weapons.

[Cavepeople](/wiki/Cavepeople "Cavepeople") start with a +2 sling and a stack of rocks and [flint stones](/wiki/Flint_stone "Flint stone") to use as ammo.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[Hobbits](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit") have a 1⁄3 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a sling.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Sling skill

| Sling   |                                                                                                                       |
| ------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Max     | [Role](/wiki/Role "Role")                                                                                             |
| Basic   | - [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest"), [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist"), [Valkyrie](/wiki/Valkyrie "Valkyrie")          |
| Skilled | * [Archeologist](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist"), [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer"), [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") |
| Expert  | - [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman"), [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger")                                                 |

The sling is the only weapon that uses the **sling [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill")**. The following types of ammo use this skill as well:

- all gems
- all gray stones
- rocks

There are no [artifact](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") slings; of note is that [the Heart of Ahriman](/wiki/The_Heart_of_Ahriman "The Heart of Ahriman") is slightly more effective than a regular [luckstone](/wiki/Luckstone "Luckstone") when slung.

## Strategy

While actively training the sling skill is generally a waste of slots, players may wish to use one as a form of ranged attack early on - ammunition for it is thankfully plentiful, though most slung projectiles will [mulch](/wiki/Mulch "Mulch") when they hit [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster"), with the exception of non-flint [gray stones](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone"). None of these [projectiles](/wiki/Projectile "Projectile") can be enchanted, but blessing them grants a [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck")-based bonus to avoid breaking - even so, their usefulness overall tapers off well before the mid-game.

Flint stones are the best projectiles for slinging by far due to their 1d6 damage (averaging 3.5), but are quite rare outside of [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones"), making them difficult to take advantage of multishot with; rocks deal lower damage in comparison, but can be readily made and found everywhere. [Worthless glass](/wiki/Worthless_glass "Worthless glass") deals the same damage as rocks when slung, but weighs only 1 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum") to a single rock's 10.

Caveman that avoid using their starting flint stones until they have maximum Luck can bless them and have them last for a significant portion of the game, while [Rangers](/wiki/Rangers "Rangers") can use a sling on less threatening monsters in the early game to preserve their [arrows](/wiki/Arrow "Arrow") or [crossbow bolts](/wiki/Crossbow_bolt "Crossbow bolt") until they find a means of enchanting them and boosting their [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck"). However, these are incredibly niche approaches - Cavemen can get incredible mileage out of an aklys, Rangers have better projectile options, and generally the average player will prefer using their better ammo or weapons over an early-game death.

## History

The sling first appears in Hack 1.21, a variant of [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is included in the initial item list for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0"). In these versions, slings can be used to fire [sling bullets](/wiki/Sling_bullet "Sling bullet")[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) - rocks did not yet exist in Hack 1.21, and were first included as objects in Hack 1.0.

In [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"), the sling bullet is removed from the list of objects in [objects.c](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.0.0/objects.c "Source:NetHack 3.0.0/objects.c"), and rocks effectively take over their role as sling ammo, while [NetHack 3.2.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.2.0 "NetHack 3.2.0") introduces the flint stone as additional ammo and moves both to the "Gems/Stones" section of the [inventory](/wiki/Inventory "Inventory").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Sling (weapon)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sling_\(weapon\) "wikipedia:Sling (weapon)")***

[![](/images/thumb/8/8e/Weapon_Sling_1.jpg/150px-Weapon_Sling_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Weapon_Sling_1.jpg)



Shepherd's sling

The sling is a widespread weapon dating back to Neolithic cultures (if not still-older ones), and was typically used for hunting and combat - it is incredibly inexpensive and easy to build and use, and was thus incredibly common among shepherds, hunters and other "common" folk. As a result, while man-made sling bullets and rocks used as sling ammunition are frequently salvaged during archeological expeditions, intact slings are much harder to find. Slinging is a tradition among the peoples of the Balearic Islands, who are known since classical times as proficient mercenaries.

Slinging as a sport is still practiced in the Balearic Islands and other areas in modern times, and the sling is also used as an improvised weapon for wildnerness survival, hurling incendiary devices such as [Molotov cocktails](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molotov_cocktail "wikipedia:Molotov cocktail") and [grenades](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grenade "wikipedia:Grenade") with additional range, and other more hobby-oriented purposes. A skilled slinger can fire projectiles at distances upwards of 450 meters (1500 feet) at speeds over 250 miles per hour.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

Slings appear in all editions of *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* as a common ranged weapon for clerics ([Priest(esse)s](/wiki/Priest "Priest") in *NetHack*), who cannot use other non-blunt projectiles, due to being forbidden from shedding blood. Their corresponding [sling bullets](/wiki/Sling_bullets "Sling bullets") deal *1d4* base damage.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) *Dungeons & Dragons* also has a rule that improvised stones do one size category less in damage, i.e. *1d3* instead of *1d4* - this may be reflected by the lower damage in modern *NetHack*. Slings also appear in the third version of *[Rogue](/wiki/Rogue "Rogue")*, with its corresponding rock dealing the same damage as in *D\&D*.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6) The usefulness of slings in other media tends to vary, but it tends to be considered somewhat more useful than it is perceived as in *NetHack*.

## Variants

Some [variants](/wiki/Variant "Variant") aim to make slings more viable as a weapon.

### SporkHack

In [SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack"), the [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") of [Giantslayer](/wiki/Giantslayer "Giantslayer") is changed to a sling that has +1d5 to-hit as before, deals +1d8 against [giant humanoids](/wiki/Giant_humanoid "Giant humanoid") and [warns of them](/wiki/Warned_of_monster_type "Warned of monster type") while wielded, and sets the wielder's [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") to 18/\*\* even if it occupies the alternate weapon slot.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), Giantslayer's base item is also changed to a sling. It has +1d5 to-hit, deals double damage against [giants](/wiki/Giant_\(monster_attribute\) "Giant (monster attribute)"), and while wielded it warns of giants and sets the wielder's strength to 18/\*\* - as in SporkHack, this can happen even if the artifact is in the alternate weapon slot.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), slings gain a strength-based bonus damage (with a maximum of +8 from 25 strength), and Cavemen gain a +1 bonus to multishot when using them.

[Enki](/wiki/Spirits_\(dNetHack\)#Enki.2C_God_of_the_First_City "Spirits (dNetHack)") is a spirit that grants skill in slings while bound. [Shiro](/wiki/Shiro "Shiro") has a passive power that pelts a target with a volley of rocks using the sling skill for damage.

The [silver slingstone](/index.php?title=Silver_slingstone\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Silver slingstone (page does not exist)") is introduced as ammo that can be used against [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver")-hating monsters, and can be found is small deposits within rock or in large amounts on a certain level in the [Neutral Quest](/wiki/Neutral_Quest_\(dNetHack\) "Neutral Quest (dNetHack)"). Silver slingstones fired at 25 strength from a sling out-damage even +7 [silver arrows](/wiki/Silver_arrow "Silver arrow") - this has earned dNetHack's slings the nickname of "portable meteor launchers".

### DynaHack

In [DynaHack](/wiki/DynaHack "DynaHack"), slings gain a damage bonus based on enchantment and the character's strength, making them much more viable as a ranged weapon.

### EvilHack

[EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") reintroduces sling bullets in version 0.7.1. Cavepeople of all types start with sling bullets.

[Giant](/wiki/Giant_\(starting_race\) "Giant (starting race)") characters take extra damage from sling-fired projectiles.

The presence of sling bullets and the ability to [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") them makes slings quite viable for other characters: Priests in particular are restricted from using any edged or piercing weapons, leaving slings as one of their few ranged options.

Hobbits have the same chance of generated with a sling as in *NetHack*, as do [hobbit pickpockets](/wiki/Hobbit_pickpocket "Hobbit pickpocket"), and both monsters generate with either sling bullets (1⁄3 chance) or flint stones (2⁄3 chance) as ammo. [Player monster](/wiki/Player_monster_\(EvilHack\) "Player monster (EvilHack)") cavepeople will always generate with slings, along with flint stones and sling bullets to use as ammo.

### SlashTHEM

[SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") adds [David's Sling](/index.php?title=David%27s_Sling\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "David's Sling (page does not exist)"), an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") sling that has +5 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") and double damage, grants [half physical damage](/wiki/Half_physical_damage "Half physical damage") while wielded, and instakills any giant humanoid hit by projectiles fired from it.

[Hobbit](/wiki/Hobbit_\(starting_race\) "Hobbit (starting race)") characters can always reach at least Skilled in slings.

### Hack'EM

[Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM") adds David's Sling from SlashTHEM and significantly changes its properties: the sling grants +6 damage to projectiles that it fires, deals double damage against giants, and confers warning of giants in addition to half physical damage while wielded.

## Encyclopedia entry

And it came to pass, when the Philistine arose, and came and  
drew nigh to meet David, that David hasted, and ran toward  
the army to meet the Philistine.  
And David put his hand in his bag, and took thence a stone,  
and slang it, and smote the Philistine in his forehead, that  
the stone sunk into his forehead; and he fell upon his face  
to the earth.  
So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and with  
a stone, and smote the Philistine, and slew him; but there  
was no sword in the hand of David.

\[ 1 Samuel 17:48-50 ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 53](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L53)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 360](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L360)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [Hack 1.0.2 partl](http://homepages.cwi.nl/~aeb/games/hack/1.0.2-part1) (objects.h, line 620), Andries Brouwer @ cwi.nl
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) <http://www.slinging.org/>
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) <http://www.dandwiki.com/wiki/SRD:Sling>
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) <http://rogue.rogueforge.net/vade-mecum/>

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Sling

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
English

 • 中文（中国大陆）‎
)
Name sling
Appearance sling
Damage vs. small d2
Damage vs. large d2
To-hit bonus +0
Weapon skill sling
Size one-handed
Base price 20 zm
(+10/positive
enchant)
Weight 3
Material leather

A sling is a type of weapon that appears in NetHack, and is a launcher designed for rocks, gems, and gray stones; these projectiles can be multishot when fired from a sling.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Sling skill
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 Origin
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SporkHack
    • 6.2 UnNetHack
    • 6.3 dNetHack
    • 6.4 DynaHack
    • 6.5 EvilHack
    • 6.6 SlashTHEM
    • 6.7 Hack'EM
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry
  • 8 References

Generation

Slings make up 4% of all randomly-generated weapons.

Cavepeople start with a +2 sling and a stack of rocks and flint stones to use as ammo.[1]

Hobbits have a 1⁄3 chance of being generated with a sling.[2]

Sling skill

Sling
Max Role
Basic
  • Priest, Tourist, Valkyrie
Skilled
  • Archeologist, Healer, Wizard
Expert
  • Caveman, Ranger

The sling is the only weapon that uses the sling skill. The following types of ammo use this skill as well:

  • all gems
  • all gray stones
  • rocks

There are no artifact slings; of note is that the Heart of Ahriman is slightly more effective than a regular luckstone when slung.

Strategy

While actively training the sling skill is generally a waste of slots, players may wish to use one as a form of ranged attack early on - ammunition for it is thankfully plentiful, though most slung projectiles will mulch when they hit monsters, with the exception of non-flint gray stones. None of these projectiles can be enchanted, but blessing them grants a Luck-based bonus to avoid breaking - even so, their usefulness overall tapers off well before the mid-game.

Flint stones are the best projectiles for slinging by far due to their 1d6 damage (averaging 3.5), but are quite rare outside of bones, making them difficult to take advantage of multishot with; rocks deal lower damage in comparison, but can be readily made and found everywhere. Worthless glass deals the same damage as rocks when slung, but weighs only 1 aum to a single rock's 10.

Caveman that avoid using their starting flint stones until they have maximum Luck can bless them and have them last for a significant portion of the game, while Rangers can use a sling on less threatening monsters in the early game to preserve their arrows or crossbow bolts until they find a means of enchanting them and boosting their Luck. However, these are incredibly niche approaches - Cavemen can get incredible mileage out of an aklys, Rangers have better projectile options, and generally the average player will prefer using their better ammo or weapons over an early-game death.

History

The sling first appears in Hack 1.21, a variant of Jay Fenlason's Hack, and is included in the initial item list for Hack 1.0. In these versions, slings can be used to fire sling bullets[3] - rocks did not yet exist in Hack 1.21, and were first included as objects in Hack 1.0.

In NetHack 3.0.0, the sling bullet is removed from the list of objects in objects.c, and rocks effectively take over their role as sling ammo, while NetHack 3.2.0 introduces the flint stone as additional ammo and moves both to the "Gems/Stones" section of the inventory.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Sling (weapon)
Shepherd's sling

The sling is a widespread weapon dating back to Neolithic cultures (if not still-older ones), and was typically used for hunting and combat - it is incredibly inexpensive and easy to build and use, and was thus incredibly common among shepherds, hunters and other "common" folk. As a result, while man-made sling bullets and rocks used as sling ammunition are frequently salvaged during archeological expeditions, intact slings are much harder to find. Slinging is a tradition among the peoples of the Balearic Islands, who are known since classical times as proficient mercenaries.

Slinging as a sport is still practiced in the Balearic Islands and other areas in modern times, and the sling is also used as an improvised weapon for wildnerness survival, hurling incendiary devices such as Molotov cocktails and grenades with additional range, and other more hobby-oriented purposes. A skilled slinger can fire projectiles at distances upwards of 450 meters (1500 feet) at speeds over 250 miles per hour.[4]

Slings appear in all editions of Dungeons & Dragons as a common ranged weapon for clerics (Priest(esse)s in NetHack), who cannot use other non-blunt projectiles, due to being forbidden from shedding blood. Their corresponding sling bullets deal 1d4 base damage.[5] Dungeons & Dragons also has a rule that improvised stones do one size category less in damage, i.e. 1d3 instead of 1d4 - this may be reflected by the lower damage in modern NetHack. Slings also appear in the third version of Rogue, with its corresponding rock dealing the same damage as in D&D.[6] The usefulness of slings in other media tends to vary, but it tends to be considered somewhat more useful than it is perceived as in NetHack.

Variants

Some variants aim to make slings more viable as a weapon.

SporkHack

In SporkHack, the base item of Giantslayer is changed to a sling that has +1d5 to-hit as before, deals +1d8 against giant humanoids and warns of them while wielded, and sets the wielder's strength to 18/** even if it occupies the alternate weapon slot.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, Giantslayer's base item is also changed to a sling. It has +1d5 to-hit, deals double damage against giants, and while wielded it warns of giants and sets the wielder's strength to 18/** - as in SporkHack, this can happen even if the artifact is in the alternate weapon slot.

dNetHack

In dNetHack and notdNetHack, slings gain a strength-based bonus damage (with a maximum of +8 from 25 strength), and Cavemen gain a +1 bonus to multishot when using them.

Enki is a spirit that grants skill in slings while bound. Shiro has a passive power that pelts a target with a volley of rocks using the sling skill for damage.

The silver slingstone is introduced as ammo that can be used against silver-hating monsters, and can be found is small deposits within rock or in large amounts on a certain level in the Neutral Quest. Silver slingstones fired at 25 strength from a sling out-damage even +7 silver arrows - this has earned dNetHack's slings the nickname of "portable meteor launchers".

DynaHack

In DynaHack, slings gain a damage bonus based on enchantment and the character's strength, making them much more viable as a ranged weapon.

EvilHack

EvilHack reintroduces sling bullets in version 0.7.1. Cavepeople of all types start with sling bullets.

Giant characters take extra damage from sling-fired projectiles.

The presence of sling bullets and the ability to forge them makes slings quite viable for other characters: Priests in particular are restricted from using any edged or piercing weapons, leaving slings as one of their few ranged options.

Hobbits have the same chance of generated with a sling as in NetHack, as do hobbit pickpockets, and both monsters generate with either sling bullets (1⁄3 chance) or flint stones (2⁄3 chance) as ammo. Player monster cavepeople will always generate with slings, along with flint stones and sling bullets to use as ammo.

SlashTHEM

SlashTHEM adds David's Sling, an artifact sling that has +5 to-hit and double damage, grants half physical damage while wielded, and instakills any giant humanoid hit by projectiles fired from it.

Hobbit characters can always reach at least Skilled in slings.

Hack'EM

Hack'EM adds David's Sling from SlashTHEM and significantly changes its properties: the sling grants +6 damage to projectiles that it fires, deals double damage against giants, and confers warning of giants in addition to half physical damage while wielded.

Encyclopedia entry

And it came to pass, when the Philistine arose, and came and
drew nigh to meet David, that David hasted, and ran toward
the army to meet the Philistine.
And David put his hand in his bag, and took thence a stone,
and slang it, and smote the Philistine in his forehead, that
the stone sunk into his forehead; and he fell upon his face
to the earth.
So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and with
a stone, and smote the Philistine, and slew him; but there
was no sword in the hand of David.

[ 1 Samuel 17:48-50 ]

A '''sling''' is a type of [[weapon]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]'', and is a [[launcher]] designed for [[rock]]s, [[gem]]s, and [[gray stone]]s; these projectiles can be [[multishot]] when [[fire]]d from a sling.

==Generation==
Slings make up 4% of all randomly-generated weapons.

[[Cavepeople]] start with a +2 sling and a stack of rocks and [[flint stone]]s to use as ammo.{{refsrc|src/u_init.c|53|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

[[Hobbit]]s have a {{frac|3}} chance of [[monster starting inventory|being generated with]] a sling.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|360|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

==Sling skill==
{{sling skill table}}

The sling is the only weapon that uses the '''sling [[skill]]'''. The following types of ammo use this skill as well:

* all gems
* all gray stones
* rocks

There are no [[artifact weapon|artifact]] slings; of note is that [[the Heart of Ahriman]] is slightly more effective than a regular [[luckstone]] when slung.

==Strategy==
While actively training the sling skill is generally a waste of slots, players may wish to use one as a form of ranged attack early on - ammunition for it is thankfully plentiful, though most slung projectiles will [[mulch]] when they hit [[monster]]s, with the exception of non-flint [[gray stone]]s. None of these [[projectile]]s can be enchanted, but blessing them grants a [[Luck]]-based bonus to avoid breaking - even so, their usefulness overall tapers off well before the mid-game.

Flint stones are the best projectiles for slinging by far due to their 1d6 damage (averaging 3.5), but are quite rare outside of [[bones]], making them difficult to take advantage of multishot with; rocks deal lower damage in comparison, but can be readily made and found everywhere. [[Worthless glass]] deals the same damage as rocks when slung, but weighs only 1 [[aum]] to a single rock's 10.

Caveman that avoid using their starting flint stones until they have maximum Luck can bless them and have them last for a significant portion of the game, while [[Rangers]] can use a sling on less threatening monsters in the early game to preserve their [[arrow]]s or [[crossbow bolt]]s until they find a means of enchanting them and boosting their [[Luck]]. However, these are incredibly niche approaches - Cavemen can get incredible mileage out of an aklys, Rangers have better projectile options, and generally the average player will prefer using their better ammo or weapons over an early-game death.

==History==
The sling first appears in Hack 1.21, a variant of [[Jay Fenlason's Hack]], and is included in the initial item list for [[Hack 1.0]]. In these versions, slings can be used to fire [[sling bullet]]s<ref>[http://homepages.cwi.nl/~aeb/games/hack/1.0.2-part1 Hack 1.0.2 partl] (objects.h, line 620), Andries Brouwer @ cwi.nl</ref> - rocks did not yet exist in Hack 1.21, and were first included as objects in Hack 1.0.

In [[NetHack 3.0.0]], the sling bullet is removed from the list of objects in [[Source:NetHack_3.0.0/objects.c|objects.c]], and rocks effectively take over their role as sling ammo, while [[NetHack 3.2.0]] introduces the flint stone as additional ammo and moves both to the "Gems/Stones" section of the [[inventory]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Sling (weapon)}}
[[File:Weapon Sling 1.jpg|thumb|150px|Shepherd's sling]]
The sling is a widespread weapon dating back to Neolithic cultures (if not still-older ones), and was typically used for hunting and combat - it is incredibly inexpensive and easy to build and use, and was thus incredibly common among shepherds, hunters and other "common" folk. As a result, while man-made sling bullets and rocks used as sling ammunition are frequently salvaged during archeological expeditions, intact slings are much harder to find. Slinging is a tradition among the peoples of the Balearic Islands, who are known since classical times as proficient mercenaries.

Slinging as a sport is still practiced in the Balearic Islands and other areas in modern times, and the sling is also used as an improvised weapon for wildnerness survival, hurling incendiary devices such as [[wikipedia:Molotov cocktail|Molotov cocktails]] and [[wikipedia:Grenade|grenades]] with additional range, and other more hobby-oriented purposes. A skilled slinger can fire projectiles at distances upwards of 450 meters (1500 feet) at speeds over 250 miles per hour.<ref>http://www.slinging.org/</ref>

Slings appear in all editions of ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' as a common ranged weapon for clerics ([[Priest|Priest(esse)s]] in ''NetHack''), who cannot use other non-blunt projectiles, due to being forbidden from shedding blood. Their corresponding [[sling bullets]] deal ''1d4'' base damage.<ref>http://www.dandwiki.com/wiki/SRD:Sling</ref> ''Dungeons & Dragons'' also has a rule that improvised stones do one size category less in damage, i.e. ''1d3'' instead of ''1d4'' - this may be reflected by the lower damage in modern ''NetHack''. Slings also appear in the third version of ''[[Rogue]]'', with its corresponding rock dealing the same damage as in ''D&D''.<ref>http://rogue.rogueforge.net/vade-mecum/</ref> The usefulness of slings in other media tends to vary, but it tends to be considered somewhat more useful than it is perceived as in ''NetHack''.

==Variants==
Some [[variant]]s aim to make slings more viable as a weapon.

===SporkHack===
In [[SporkHack]], the [[base item]] of [[Giantslayer]] is changed to a sling that has +1d5 to-hit as before, deals +1d8 against [[giant humanoid]]s and [[Warned of monster type|warns of them]] while wielded, and sets the wielder's [[strength]] to 18/** even if it occupies the alternate weapon slot.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], Giantslayer's base item is also changed to a sling. It has +1d5 to-hit, deals double damage against [[Giant (monster attribute)|giants]], and while wielded it warns of giants and sets the wielder's strength to 18/** - as in SporkHack, this can happen even if the artifact is in the alternate weapon slot.

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]] and [[notdNetHack]], slings gain a strength-based bonus damage (with a maximum of +8 from 25 strength), and Cavemen gain a +1 bonus to multishot when using them.

[[Spirits (dNetHack)#Enki, God of the First City|Enki]] is a spirit that grants skill in slings while bound. [[Shiro]] has a passive power that pelts a target with a volley of rocks using the sling skill for damage.

The [[silver slingstone]] is introduced as ammo that can be used against [[silver]]-hating monsters, and can be found is small deposits within rock or in large amounts on a certain level in the [[Neutral Quest (dNetHack)|Neutral Quest]]. Silver slingstones fired at 25 strength from a sling out-damage even +7 [[silver arrow]]s - this has earned dNetHack's slings the nickname of "portable meteor launchers".

===DynaHack===
In [[DynaHack]], slings gain a damage bonus based on enchantment and the character's strength, making them much more viable as a ranged weapon.

===EvilHack===
[[EvilHack]] reintroduces sling bullets in version 0.7.1. Cavepeople of all types start with sling bullets.

[[Giant (starting race)|Giant]] characters take extra damage from sling-fired projectiles.

The presence of sling bullets and the ability to [[Forge (dungeon feature)|forge]] them makes slings quite viable for other characters: Priests in particular are restricted from using any edged or piercing weapons, leaving slings as one of their few ranged options. 

Hobbits have the same chance of generated with a sling as in ''NetHack'', as do [[hobbit pickpocket]]s, and both monsters generate with either sling bullets ({{frac|3}} chance) or flint stones ({{frac|2|3}} chance) as ammo. [[Player monster (EvilHack)|Player monster]] cavepeople will always generate with slings, along with flint stones and sling bullets to use as ammo.

===SlashTHEM===
[[SlashTHEM]] adds [[David's Sling]], an [[artifact]] sling that has +5 [[to-hit]] and double damage, grants [[half physical damage]] while wielded, and instakills any giant humanoid hit by projectiles fired from it.

[[Hobbit (starting race)|Hobbit]] characters can always reach at least Skilled in slings.

===Hack'EM===
[[Hack'EM]] adds David's Sling from SlashTHEM and significantly changes its properties: the sling grants +6 damage to projectiles that it fires, deals double damage against giants, and confers warning of giants in addition to half physical damage while wielded.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
And it came to pass, when the Philistine arose, and came and
drew nigh to meet David, that David hasted, and ran toward
the army to meet the Philistine.
And David put his hand in his bag, and took thence a stone,
and slang it, and smote the Philistine in his forehead, that
the stone sunk into his forehead; and he fell upon his face
to the earth.
So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and with
a stone, and smote the Philistine, and slew him; but there
was no sword in the hand of David.
|[ 1 Samuel 17:48-50 ]
}}
